stream_context.summary: Kaze continues building Course 11 (an oil-rig/industrial harbor level inspired by Sunshine’s Rico Harbor), focusing on new moving platform assets, zipline visuals/behavior, cannons for traversal, and a major lighting change (adding a camera-facing fill light). The stream includes debugging a regression that broke ziplines due to an earlier collision optimization, N64 hardware testing that reveals clip-ratio rendering issues, and discussion of future plans like split-screen multiplayer during an upcoming vacation block.
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces a project-wide lighting change, uncovers and fixes a months-old collision regression affecting ziplines, identifies N64 clip-ratio rendering failures, and reveals that Kaze is replacing libultra with an optimized custom version (affecting cannon reticle rendering). Also contains clear statements of design philosophy (avoiding options and “instructional” guidance) and concrete future plans (possible split-screen multiplayer during vacation).

findings.summary: Kaze shows Course 11 as an oil-rig/industrial platforming course with many bespoke moving platform types (left-right, in-out, rotating cranes, hooks, shrink/grow platforms, seesaw-like oil mechanism) meant to be combined into traversal challenges.

Course 11’s look is intentionally inspired by Mario Sunshine’s Rico Harbor, including recolored Rico Harbor textures; Kaze is slightly disappointed the inspiration is easily recognizable because he hoped it would feel less overt.

Kaze implements a major lighting change across the game: adding a camera-facing fill light so characters/objects aren’t too dark and scenes read better, while still keeping the “N64 look” as a base. Some level lights temporarily break due to the in-progress change.

Ziplines stop working due to a regression traced to an earlier collision optimization: Kaze had changed ceiling-raycast/collision code months ago, didn’t test it, and a bracket/logic mistake offset the ceiling detection so Mario wouldn’t grab/hang. He fixes it quickly once identified.
findings.quote: A few months ago I found an optimization with collision… but when I did that, I messed up the code and I actually never tested it.

findings.summary: N64 hardware testing reveals a rendering failure (‘melting’ geometry / graphics-thread freeze) linked to a clip-ratio change. The clip-ratio tweak improves FPS but appears to break rendering stability; Kaze considers reverting it if needed.

Cannons are being added as optional traversal tools between buildings (not mandatory for progression). While testing, Kaze finds the cannon reticle rendering is offset/rotated incorrectly and suspects it’s caused by his custom optimized libultra replacement affecting matrix/transform routines. He decides to replace the reticle with a cheaper new one rather than patch the old path.
findings.quote: We don't use libultra anymore, I'm making my own optimized libultra. It's probably fucked up along here.

findings.summary: Kaze rejects adding player-facing toggles for fundamental mechanics (example: toggling swim mechanics for ‘purist’ vs. other styles) because he prefers a single authored experience except for accessibility-like options (e.g., button swapping).
findings.quote: I'm kind of against giving players options… I think it's weird to give the player an option to select how a fundamental thing like that works.

findings.summary: Kaze pushes back on adding “trajectory guide lines” for cannons because it turns play into following developer instructions rather than player-driven exploration; he frames freedom and self-directed decision-making as a core design goal.
findings.quote: I think games should be about experiencing freedom… I don't want the dev telling me, hey, do this, please.

findings.summary: Zeina shares progress on a boss walk-cycle animation (for the unfinished Buzzer boss fight) and discusses constraints like keeping the head locked to always look at Mario to feel creepier. Kaze invites additional feedback via Discord.

Kaze checks in with Lilaa about the status of quaternion animations/exporter work; Lilaa indicates it’s ‘done’ and involves exporter-side changes. Kaze reviews a UI/tool card Lilaa shares and flags uncertainties about reapplying settings across animation switches and unclear fields like HandleGroups/HandleAnimationTables.

Kaze notes overall project progress: Course 11 development is underway; the last finished level is “Buzzer 2” (showcase). The Buzzer boss fight is still blocked on animations, with the walk cycle being one of the last remaining pieces.

Kaze says releasing this year is unlikely because they are only around Course 11 and he has limited time; he wants to release only when fully finished. He also states he’s now streaming on YouTube instead of Twitch due to ad experience and control over ads.

biobak.summary: Biobak previously suggested a red/ashy coloration approach for the oil (a ‘running red ash’ look). Kaze acknowledges the idea but observes players misread it as lava/burning, prompting palette iteration.
biobak.quote: The red makes it look like running red ash. That was Biobak's idea.

badub.summary: Kaze reiterates the stream OST is custom-made by Badub, minimizing copyright risk, though some tracks are remixes of Mario music (an accepted risk given the project is a Mario game).
badub.quote: All of the OST is custom made by Badub.

zeina.summary: Zeina presents a new walk-cycle iteration for the boss and helps critique it (arm motion feels ‘Bowser-like’), while enforcing the design constraint that the head should not move so the boss can keep eye contact with Mario.

Zeina and Kaze banter about potentially doing an intensive daily-stream sprint if Kaze tackles multiplayer during his vacation, and Zeina flags practical concerns like needing time to prepare (e.g., cooking/house routines).

findings.summary: Lilaa indicates quaternion animation/exporter work is complete (or near-complete) and seems to involve exporter changes; Kaze reacts positively but hasn’t validated integration yet.

Lilaa requests N64-side testing of Koopa Wave Cove with the new lighting; Kaze attempts hardware testing and uses it to evaluate lighting and performance, which leads into diagnosing clip-ratio rendering issues.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I think games should be about experiencing freedom… I don't want the dev telling me, hey, do this, please.
memorable_quotes.context: Explaining why he refuses trajectory guide lines for cannon shots; frames a core philosophy for building ‘new but respectful’ Mario 64 content.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: A few months ago I found an optimization with collision… but when I did that, I messed up the code and I actually never tested it.
memorable_quotes.context: Owning a months-old regression that broke zipline ceiling detection; reveals his speed-first workflow and its risks.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I'm kind of against giving players options… I think it's weird to give the player an option to select how a fundamental thing like that works.
memorable_quotes.context: Rejecting a proposed toggle for swim mechanics; highlights preference for a single authored experience over configurability.

key_stories.title: Zipline regression caused by untested collision optimization
key_stories.summary: While trying to implement/preview ziplines in the oil-rig course, Kaze discovers Mario no longer grabs the ceiling/zipline correctly. He traces it to a collision/ceiling raycast optimization he made months earlier and never properly tested, then fixes the logic/bracketing issue quickly once found.
key_stories.challenge: Ziplines appear ‘broken’—Mario fails to start hanging because ceiling detection isn’t triggering.
key_stories.process: Kaze debugs by adding crude breakpoints (killing Mario when hit), printing ceiling values, and inspecting the ceiling-finding code path; he identifies an offset/logic mistake introduced during an optimization meant to skip iterating over most collision surfaces.
key_stories.outcome: Bug is fixed rapidly; Kaze acknowledges the trade-off between speed and testing, and labels it a regression incident that “QA” would normally catch.
key_stories.key_quote: See that's the thing with me. I never test my code. I just assume it works.

key_stories.title: N64 clip-ratio performance tweak creates rendering instability
key_stories.summary: Kaze boots the hack on real N64 hardware to evaluate performance and lighting. The build runs impressively fast (around the low 40s FPS in the test), but a clip-ratio change causes extreme visual artifacts (‘melting’ geometry) and can freeze the graphics thread.
key_stories.challenge: Improve FPS while keeping N64 rendering stable and readable under the new lighting approach.
key_stories.process: Kaze reproduces the issue on console, recognizes the artifact pattern as related to far/near clipping and triangle distance, and correlates it to his recent clip-ratio adjustment.
key_stories.outcome: He concludes the clip-ratio change likely needs deeper investigation or a straightforward revert if it isn’t worth the instability, despite the FPS gain.

key_stories.title: Optional traversal tools without ‘developer hand-holding’
key_stories.summary: While placing cannons to shoot between buildings in the oil-rig course, Kaze discusses adding optional traversal aids that speed exploration but do not gate progression. He rejects UI guidance like trajectory lines because it would reduce player agency and turn play into following instructions.
key_stories.challenge: Make traversal tools readable and usable without trivializing skill or discovery.
key_stories.process: Kaze compares ‘guided’ designs (trajectory lines/rings) against his desired experience of freedom and self-directed choice, and frames failure (dying from a cannon shot) as acceptable when the cannon is optional.
key_stories.outcome: Cannons remain optional, and Kaze prioritizes player experimentation over explicit guidance.
key_stories.key_quote: If we do that, I fear that you're not gonna feel the sense of freedom.

open_questions.topic: Camera-facing fill light implementation and art direction
open_questions.context: Kaze adds a camera-facing light to brighten moving objects/characters and improve scene readability, inspired by watching Mario Odyssey footage; some level lighting is temporarily broken while he integrates it.
questions: What exactly did you change in the lighting pipeline (extra light source, per-object vertex lighting adjustment, material change, or a post-like trick) and how invasive was it in the decomp code?
How did you decide the fill intensity/color so it stays ‘authentic N64’ rather than looking modern/flat?
Which levels benefited the most, and did any levels lose intended mood (e.g., caves becoming less grim)?

open_questions.context: A collision optimization intended to skip iterating most surfaces introduced a ceiling-detection bug that broke ziplines months later; Kaze admits he often doesn’t test changes immediately.
questions: What was the original collision optimization (spatial partitioning, early-outs, bounding checks), and how big was the performance win?
What’s your current testing strategy for catching regressions in a large ROM hack—do you have a set of ‘must-test’ levels/mechanics (ziplines, ceiling grab, wall kick, etc.)?
Has this ‘optimize now, test later’ workflow ever caused a near-release crisis, and did it change how you work with contributors?

open_questions.context: Kaze observes clip-ratio changes raise FPS but create major rendering artifacts and even freeze the graphics thread on N64 hardware.
questions: What clip-ratio parameters did you change (near plane, far plane, FOV-related values), and what FPS improvement did you measure?
Is the artifact a known N64 hardware limitation, an RSP/RDP precision issue, or an interaction with your optimized rendering code?
What’s the decision rule: revert for stability, or keep and constrain level geometry to avoid the failure case?

open_questions.context: Kaze believes the cannon reticle transform/offset bug is due to replacing libultra with his own optimized version, affecting matrix/translation routines. He opts to redesign the reticle rather than debug the existing render path.
questions: Why did you decide to replace libultra—performance, control, portability, or removing overhead?
Which subsystems have you rewritten so far (math/matrix, scheduling, audio, input), and what kinds of bugs have emerged because of it?
Is the plan to upstream/open-source this library separately, and could it help other decomp-based projects?

open_questions.context: Kaze says his job gives him two weeks off at the end of June, during which he ‘might add multiplayer with split-screen,’ possibly with daily streams if Zeina can tolerate it.
questions: What multiplayer model are you aiming for (co-op campaign, competitive mini-modes, battle arenas), and what’s the minimum viable version?
What are the biggest technical blockers in SM64 decomp for split-screen (camera system, rendering twice, performance budget, memory), and what optimizations make it plausible now?
How would you design levels/objectives to respect both single-player and multiplayer without compromising either?
